thread.title: The Sun Remembers This Week in Baltimore Sports: Oct. 11-17
thread.title_full: The Sun Remembers This Week in Baltimore Sports: Oct. 11-17

title: The Sun Remembers This Week in Baltimore Sports: Oct. 11-17
text:
In Game 6 of the ALCS, Tony Fernandez hits the eventual game-winning home run off Armando Benitez in the 11th inning. (Karl Merton Feron, Baltimore Sun, 1997) 
By Mike Klingaman The Baltimore Sun 
Oct. 12, 2003: The Ravens defeat the Arizona Cardinals in Tempe despite a sorry performance by quarterback Kyle Boller, who passes for 72 yards — the second-lowest total in team history. Chris McAlister scores on an 83-yard interception return, Ed Reed scores on a 22-yard runback of a blocked punt and Matt Stover kicks four field goals for Baltimore. 
Oct. 15, 1997: Cleveland’s 1-0 victory over the Orioles in 11 innings in Game 6 of the American League Championship Series at Camden Yards sends the Cleveland Indians to the World Series. A home run by Tony Fernandez off reliever Armando Benitez sinks the Orioles, who go 0-for-12 with runners in scoring position. 
Oct. 11, 1975: “Earl [Weaver] has to be doing something right to get us into three World Series and into the ALCS in five of the last six years,” Orioles general manager Frank Cashen says in giving the manager a $5,000 raise. Weaver, 45, earns an estimated $80,000. 
Oct. 17, 1971: Pittsburgh defeats the Orioles, 2-1, at Memorial Stadium to win the World Series in seven games. The Pirates’ Steve Blass stops Baltimore on four hits for his second complete-game win in the Series. 
Oct. 11, 1969: Towson State routs Frostburg State, 53-16, for its first-ever intercollegiate football victory. Al Dodds passes for five touchdowns and runs for one as the Tigers (1-3) score 35 points in the fourth quarter. 
Oct. 16, 1964: Charley Pittman rushes for two touchdowns as Edmondson rips Gilman, 27-0. It’s the 15th straight win for coach Augie Waibel’s Redskins. 
Oct. 13, 1957: A 38-point second-half rally carries the undefeated Colts past the Green Bay Packers, 45-17, in Milwaukee. Tight end Jim Mutscheller (three touchdown receptions) and fullback Alan Ameche (three TD runs) lead Baltimore. 
Oct. 11, 1939: Ceilhus Dusak, 46, a track employee at Laurel, is killed during the fourth race when he falls under the wheels of the starting gate as it’s being moved. 
Birthday 
Oct. 12, 1939: Jerry Hill, the Colts’ fullback for nine years who scored Baltimore’s only touchdown in its 16-7 loss to the New York Jets in Super Bowl III in January 1969.
